newsitem.title: JAPAN: U.K.'s Beckett says yen volatility no trade threat.
newsitem.headline: U.K.'s Beckett says yen volatility no trade threat.

text.p: Britain's new trade chief Margaret Beckett said in Tokyo on Tuesday that the yen's recent volatility was no threat to British-Japan trade.

"Any strongly traded currency is always subject to the influence of the market and so there could indeed be some movement (in yen-sterling rates), but British-Japan cooperation in industrial policy has survived many very significant movements both in sterling and in the yen," Beckett told Reuters in an interview.

Sterling fell against the yen in Tuesday's Tokyo trade on market talk, which later proved groundless, that Beckett had said there was a possibility that Britain would rejoin Europe's exchange rate mechanism (ERM).
Beckett, Secretary of Trade and Industry, arrived in Tokyo on Monday for a three-day visit to reassure Japanese business about the policies of Britain's new Labour government.
She said the relationship between Tokyo and London had become so strong that temporary currency movements were not a threat.
"So of course they're (trade ties) affected by issues like relative strength of currencies. But not so much as to affect what is actually a deeper decision about where interests lie," she said.
